did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, University of Virginia Library
did.unittitle: Letter of John Strode Barbour 1839 September 10
did.abstract: John Strode Barbour, Virginian politician, writes to Luke Lawless, Thomas Hart Benton and Leslie Linn of St. Louis, Missouri, introducing Richard Johnson Tutt, who wishes to settle in Missouri.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
See the
University of Virginia Library’s use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: John Strode Barbour Letter, 1839 September 10, Accession #11111, Special Collections Dept., University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This letter was purchased by the Library on October 19, 1993, from Timothy H. Bakken, Halvor Americana, Clarendon Hills, Illinois.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: John Strode Barbour (1790-1855), was a United States Congressman from Virginia from 1823 to 1833.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: Letter, dated September 10, 1839, from American statesman and Virginia politician John Strode Barbour (1790-1855), Culpeper, Virginia, to Hon. Luke E. Lawless, Thomas H[art] Benton, and Leslie F. Linn, St. Louis, Missouri, introducing Richard Johnson Tutt of Culpeper County, who wishes to settle in Missouri. Barbour strongly praises Tutt's unimpeachable character, intelligence, and trustworthy nature; and, he requests that they make him known in their part of the state.
